natural solution: When using the distributive property, we add the product of 16 and $2x$ to the product of 16 and 5: \begin{align} 16(2x+5) &= 16\cdot 2x+16\cdot 5\\ &= \boxed{32x+80} \end{align}

shows  "16 * (2 * x + 5) = 32 * x + 80"

 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "16 * (2 * x + 5) = 32 * x + 80"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 16 * (2 * x + 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 32 * x + 80"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x = Q x"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Expand the following expression: $16(2x+5)$ The final Answer is 32x+80
 ### Proof
 When using the distributive property, we add the product of 16 and $2x$ to the product of 16 and 5: \begin{align} 16(2x+5) &= 16\cdot 2x+16\cdot 5\\ &= \boxed{32x+80} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 16 * (2 * x + 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 32 * x + 80"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x = Q x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Show that for every real number $x$, the expressions $16(2x+5)$ and $32x+80$ are equal.
